{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3753967,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-02T17:00:49.877Z","cooked":"

Introducing YASS: Yet Another Software Suite

Hey Chief Delphi!

I know we have been hinting at this for a while and some of you may be frustrated but I promise it’s well worth the wait! We have been trying very hard to work out most of the bugs early on with these projects, and make them as accessible as possible. I hope you all enjoy them and it was worth the wait!

Over the next few days everything will update from YAGSL branded to YASS branded and we will move YAGSL under our new github org.

Check out our official announcement trailer — we’re super excited to share this with you all!

Watch the trailer:

Official Links

  • Website: https://yetanothersoftwaresuite.com
  • GitHub Organization: https://github.com/Yet-Another-Software-Suite/
  • Discord: https://discord.gg/yass
  • Instagram: https://instagram.com/yassrobotics

We’re excited to introduce YASS — Yet Another Software Suite, a modern, modular ecosystem built for FRC teams (and coming soon to FTC). YASS is designed to make robot programming simpler, faster, and more scalable, while keeping everything vendor-agnostic, sim-capable, and team-friendly.

What’s in Yet Another Software Suite?

YAMS — Yet Another Mechanism System

Docs: Yet Another Mechanism System | YAMS (yagsl.gitbook.io/yams)
Examples: github.com/…/YAMS/examples

YAMS is a high-level abstraction layer for building subsystems. It currently supports the following mechanisms, each with their own dedicated config class (except DoubleJointedArm which composes two ArmConfigs):

  • Arm
  • Elevator
  • Pivot (used for turrets and wrists)
  • Shooter
  • SwerveModule
  • SwerveDrive
  • DoubleJointedArm
  • DifferentialMechanism

All these work seamlessly with the unified SmartMotorController interface and are configured using their respective config classes, making setup consistent and easy.

YAMS provides:

  • A unified SmartMotorController interface
  • Shared config system: SmartMotorControllerConfig
  • Support for SparkMax, TalonFX, TalonFXS, ThriftyNova, SparkFlex, and (soon) ReduxNitrate
  • Helpful runtime exceptions that tell you how to fix unsupported features
  • SysId built in for Arm, Elevator, Pivot, and SmartMotorController
  • Support for same-vendor external encoders
  • Uses motor controller PID and Feedforward when available
  • Built-in fully customizable telemetry
  • Seamless simulation
  • AdvantageKit integration at the setpoint boundary
  • Live-Tuning built-in! Just enable it and change the variable fields under NT:/Tuning
  • Integration with vendor simulation!

Why YAMS?

** Simulation and real code are nearly 1:1 identical. (Only difference is the need to call .simIterate() each simulationPeriodic**

Simulate subsystems + commands with full fidelity
Test robot code without the robot
Make code reusable across hardware
Accelerate onboarding and iteration

Arms in YAMS

Elevator in YAMS

Example Code

// Create your motor controller config
SmartMotorControllerConfig motorConfig = new SmartMotorControllerConfig(this)
      .withClosedLoopController(4, 0, 0, DegreesPerSecond.of(180), DegreesPerSecondPerSecond.of(90))
      .withSoftLimit(Degrees.of(-30), Degrees.of(100))
      .withGearing(SmartMechanism.gearing(SmartMechanism.gearbox(3, 4)))
      .withIdleMode(MotorMode.BRAKE)
      .withTelemetry("ArmMotor", TelemetryVerbosity.HIGH)
      .withStatorCurrentLimit(Amps.of(40))
      .withMotorInverted(false)
      .withClosedLoopRampRate(Seconds.of(0.25))
      .withOpenLoopRampRate(Seconds.of(0.25))
      .withFeedforward(new ArmFeedforward(0, 0, 0, 0))
      .withControlMode(ControlMode.CLOSED_LOOP);

// Create your motor
TalonFXS                   armMotor    = new TalonFXS(1);
SmartMotorController       motor       = new TalonFXSWrapper(armMotor, DCMotor.getNEO(1), motorConfig);

// Create your mechanism config
ArmConfig                  config    = new ArmConfig(motor)
      .withLength(Meters.of(0.135))
      .withHardLimit(Degrees.of(-100), Degrees.of(200))
      .withTelemetry("ArmExample", TelemetryVerbosity.HIGH)
      .withMass(Pounds.of(1))
      .withStartingPosition(Degrees.of(0))
      .withExternalEncoder(armMotor.getAbsoluteEncoder())
      .withExternalEncoderInverted(true)
      .withExternalGearing(SmartMechanism.gearing(SmartMechanism.gearbox(3, 4)))
      .withUseExternalFeedbackEncoder(true)
      .withHorizontalZero(Degrees.of(0)); 

// Create the Arm!
Arm                        arm = new Arm(config);

YAMG — Yet Another Mechanism Generator

Try it now: https://yamgen.com

YAMG is a visual mechanism generator that lets you:

  • Design Arm, Elevator, and Pivot as easily as filling out a form
  • Simulate motion, constraints based off the code generator form
  • Export ready-to-use Java code compatible without using YAMS

YALL — Yet Another Limelight Library

Repo: github.com/…/YALL

YALL is a cleaned-up wrapper of LimelightHelpers.java, featuring:

  • Improved structure and full JavaDocs
  • Real-robot integration for Limelight pipelines

Note: YALL is currently the only YASS module without simulation support.

What About YAGSL?

YAGSL is now part of the YASS ecosystem and continues to be maintained and improved alongside the rest of the suite.

Huge Thanks To…

Founding Teams

  • 3481 BroncBotz
  • 9658 Camber
  • 457 Grease Monkeys
  • 3561 RoboRaiders

Partner Teams

  • 457 Grease Monkeys
  • 3561 RoboRaiders
  • 3481 BroncBotz
  • 5561 Flushing Raider Robotics (shoutout @chris_7898!)
  • 9738 Ionic Bond
  • 9658 Camber
  • 8818 The Foe
  • And many more!

What Teams Are Saying

“YAMS has made coding 10× easier. In a week I went from not being able to code at all to a functional robot. YAMS takes all the guesswork out — I’d recommend it to anyone.”
— 3561 RoboRaiders

“YAMS almost feels like a cheat code for creating high-performance subsystems. It’s extremely configurable and removes nearly all the heartache that usually comes with subsystem coding.”

“The sim support blew away our expectations — we can test the robot without the robot, increasing productivity outside of meeting hours.”

“Before YAMS, tuning performance felt like tribal knowledge. Now it’s documented, configurable, and easy to teach. New students can contribute right away.”
— 6911 SO BOTZ

“YAMS was easier to set up and led to better, more consistent results than the alternatives. The YASS team also provided top-tier support.”
— 1799 Wired Up

“Amazing documentation. There was a full setup guide explaining what every part does in context.”
— 2183 TigerBots

Special Thanks

A huge thank you to all the beta testers who helped put YASS through its paces and provided invaluable feedback. Your input made this possible!

And a very personal thank you to my wife, whose support and patience have been incredible throughout this journey.

Want to Get Involved?

  • Explore the examples
  • Use the code on your robot
  • Try the sim
  • Give feedback or submit PRs
  • Share what your team builds!
  • Join our Discord community for support, questions, and collaboration: https://discord.gg/yass

Thanks for reading — and good luck this season. We can’t wait to see what you create with YASS

— The YASS Team

Documentation brings me to All Products | Yet Another Software Suite

I would love @Eugene_Fang or @JBest opinion on it since YAMS can really help teams who are trying to follow “Scrappy not Crappy”

Scrappy, Not Crappy General Forum
Here are the slides from the talk @Eugene_Fang and I gave at the FIRST Mentor Conference: “Scrappy, Not Crappy - 604’s Unique Approaches to Solving Common Resource Constraints” (We slightly edited the slides to clear up some questions we received) We’re also working on cleaning up our pit crate CAD and will release it when it’s ready for those who are interested. Hope y’all find this useful.
","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-10-03T14:10:33.198Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":268,"readers_count":267,"score":93.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506826,"topic_slug":"introducing-yet-another-software-suite-yams-yall-yamg-yagsl","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/scrappy-not-crappy/470436","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Scrappy, Not Crappy","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL & YASS Creator "},"post_url":"/t/introducing-yet-another-software-suite-yams-yall-yamg-yagsl/506826/18","custom_user_title":"YAGSL & YASS Creator ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3754672,"name":"AmoryG","username":"AmoryG","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/amoryg/{size}/176897_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-03T15:59:33.357Z","cooked":"

When I first heard about this project, I was actually kind of skeptical. I thought it would help some teams, but at the cost of flexibility and a deep understanding of how these mechanisms actually work. After playing around with this for a bit, I’m happy to say my opinion has definitely changed. There’s plenty of flexibility and even allows for full customization with YAMG for teams that feel like YAMS doesn’t fill all their needs. And while it makes programming common mechanisms like elevators and arms a lot easier, students will still need to learn and understand core concepts to properly configure and make their mechanisms function correctly. In fact, I believe this will allow students to focus more on robotics concepts they’re actually interested in instead of overwhelming them with low level code.

I believe YASS will help raise the floor for both new and experienced teams by allowing them to work on higher level logic instead of spending days or weeks struggling to get basic code for their mechanisms working, giving teams the ability to rapidly prototype, and providing built in sim support which will allow teams to get a head start instead of rushing to get something working in time for their first competition. I’m excited to introduce this project to the rest of my team this fall. Amazing work!

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-10-03T16:00:54.921Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":265,"readers_count":264,"score":93.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506826,"topic_slug":"introducing-yet-another-software-suite-yams-yall-yamg-yagsl","display_username":"AmoryG","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10380,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2423 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/introducing-yet-another-software-suite-yams-yall-yamg-yagsl/506826/19","custom_user_title":"2423 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3754679,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-03T16:14:12.995Z","cooked":"

I really don’t know what use case YAMS doesn’t feel feature complete enough. I can see where its very very overpowered (like intake motors which just turn on/off and dont need velocity control).

Even for super complex mechanisms that you want a single mech2d for its useful bc you only need to combine all positions and calculate the joint. Then put it in your own mech2d. Ignoring all of the sim and config stuff. (I even name all of the commands from YAMS so they showup when you publish Subsystems to SmartDashboard!)

YAMG is giving someone the full code if they really don’t want to use YAMS bc they dont trust black boxes. It will ultimately be slower bc there are some tedious features that will seem like bloat if included in YAMG (like live tuning).

Do you know of anything that YAMS isn’t complete enough for?
